course.title: Understand P-H diagram and Log p-h diagram
course.description: Here, we will draw the P-H diagrams and log P-H diagrams for a refrigerant and realise its importance in understanding the refrigeration cycle.

topic.title: Objective
topic.text:
At the end of the module you will be able to:

  • Draw graph to show relation between pressure-enthalpy and temperature-enthalpy.
  • Show the thermodynamic state variables in the respective phase, by drawing the Log p-h graph.

text.t: Click the below items to learn more.

interactivity.title: Phase change
interactivity.reveal:
The pressure-enthalpy diagram describes the entropy of the refrigerant, which is the amount of enthalpy able to be transferred per Rankine (R). This diagram describes the property of a substance.

Phase change will happen when we supply heat to a substance in equilibrium.

i.e.

  • Solid - liquid equilibrium
  • Liquid - vapour equilibrium
  • Solid - vapour equilibrium

When we expand this equilibrium line to surface, the surface represents heat supplied to the substance during phase change. This is P-h diagram.

interactivity.title: Liquid Vapour Equilibrium
interactivity.reveal: In this map are included some of more important properties of the substances as temperature, pressure, specific volume, density, specific heat, enthalpy or entropy.

text.p:
A log p-h diagram shows the aggregate state of a substance, depending on pressure and heat. The vertical axis shows the logarithmic pressure and the horizontal axis shows the enthalpy with linear scaling. The logarithmic scaling makes it possible to represent processes with large pressure differences.

The diagram shown here has displays the liquid, vapour and mixture regions for the refrigerant. Liquid is found to the left (with a low energy content) - vapour to the right (with a high energy content)

In between you find the mixture of vapour and liquid in thermal equilibrium. The regions are bounded by a curve - called the saturation curve.
Represent a refrigeration cycle using Pressure - Enthalpy diagram (Log(P)-h diagram)

• The distinctive feature of the refrigeration cycle is that it runs counter-clockwise, i.e. opposite to the joule or steam cycle.
  • A change of state occurs when the refrigerant flows through one of the four main components in the refrigeration cycle.

A P-h diagram for R134a, azeotropic refrigerant, that is a pure refrigerant.

Click draw button to see the graph for constant temperature.
Now you can see a log(P)-h diagram of refrigerant R134a

topic.title: Log P–h graph of Zeotropic refrigerants

text.p:
A constant pressure, the phase changes (boiling and condensing) occur at different temperatures, that saturation temperatures of liquid and vapour (both at the same pressure) are different.

Many Zeotropic refrigerant blends have different ”dew” and ”bubble” points, e.g. one component will start boiling before another, or condense before another. In below example, the refrigerant will start boiling at 14°F at 58 psi, and be fully evaporated at (approx.) 24.8°F.

The glide will have consequenses for the superheat setting and for the evaporation temperature: Use the mean/average temperature, in this example 19.4°F as the superheat setpoint, so if you need a 18°F superheat, it would be +37.4°F.
